title: Edward Lea
text:
Edward Lea (January 31, 1837 – January 1, 1863), was an officer in the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> during the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>. He was mortally wounded at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Galveston">Battle of Galveston</a> and died in the arms of his father, who was on the opposing side in the conflict.
Biography.
Lea was born in Baltimore, Maryland, the son of Army engineer <a href="Albert%20Miller%20Lea">Albert Miller Lea</a> and Ellen Shoemaker. He entered the <a href="United%20States%20Naval%20Academy">Naval Academy</a> at Annapolis on October 2, 1851, graduating on June 9, 1855, with the rank of midshipman. Lea was employed in active service on various stations, receiving promotion to <a href="passed%20midshipman">passed midshipman</a> on April 15, 1858, to master on November 4, 1858, and to lieutenant on November 22, 1860.
Lea was serving aboard the , <a href="flagship">flagship</a> of the <a href="East%20India%20Squadron">East India Squadron</a>, when the Civil War broke out in 1861. The ship was recalled, eventually arriving in <a href="Delaware%20Bay">Delaware Bay</a> in December. Lea was soon reassigned to the , then attached to the <a href="Potomac%20Flotilla">Potomac Flotilla</a>, but was soon reassigned in her to the <a href="Gulf%20Blockading%20Squadron">Gulf Blockading Squadron</a>, where he took part in operations leading to the <a href="capture%20of%20New%20Orleans">capture of New Orleans</a> in April 1862. Lea was subsequently promoted to lieutenant commander on July 16, 1862. "Harriet Lane" pushed further up the Mississippi that July to engage enemy batteries around <a href="Vicksburg%2C%20Mississippi">Vicksburg</a>, and was then assigned to the blockade of Galveston, which she helped capture in October 1862 in the <a href="Battle%20of%20Galveston%20Harbor%20%281862%29">Battle of Galveston Harbor</a>.
When Confederate forces <a href="Battle%20of%20Galveston">retook Galveston</a> on 1 January 1863, Lea, serving as the <a href="Executive%20officer">first officer (XO)</a> of "Harriet Lane", was wounded in the abdomen and side. He subsequently succumbed to his wounds in the arms of his father, who was serving as a <a href="Major%20%28United%20States%29">major</a> of artillery in the <a href="Confederate%20Army">Confederate Army</a>, and who had witnessed the capture of the "Harriet Lane" by the gunboat from shore, and had rushed to the ship to find his son dying.
Lea and his captain, <a href="Jonathan%20Mayhew%20Wainwright%20%281821%E2%80%931863%29">Jonathan M. Wainwright</a> were buried together at the Trinity Episcopal Cemetery in Galveston. After the war Wainwright was re-interred at the <a href="United%20States%20Naval%20Academy%20Cemetery">Naval Academy Cemetery</a> in Annapolis, but when a relative suggested that Lea's remains be reburied next to his mother in the <a href="Green%20Mount%20Cemetery">Green Mount Cemetery</a>, Baltimore, Albert Lea refused, stating that his son would have preferred to remain where he had fallen in battle.
Namesake.
The destroyer was named for him, as is Camp #2 of the <a href="Sons%20of%20Union%20Veterans%20of%20the%20Civil%20War">Sons of Union Veterans of the Civil War</a> in <a href="Houston%2C%20Texas">Houston</a>.
